list.title: Question 1
list.content: For a fixed mass of gas at a constant temperature, what happens to the volume if the pressure of the gas is doubled?A.\hspace{1em}Volume will remain the sameB.\hspace{1em}Volume will doubleC.\hspace{1em}Volume will be halvedD.\hspace{1em}Volume will increase exponentially
list.markScheme: CExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:One of the laws of gases states that, for a fixed amount of gas held at a constant temperature, the volume of a gas is inversely proportional to its pressure.

list.title: Question 2
list.content: Which of the following conditions makes gases deviate from ideal behavior?A.\hspace{1em}High pressure and high temperatureB.\hspace{1em}Low pressure and low temperatureC.\hspace{1em}High pressure and low temperatureD.\hspace{1em}Low pressure and high temperature
list.markScheme: CExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:At high pressures and very low temperatures, the inter-particle forces strengthen, spaces between particles decrease causing the deviation from ideal gas behaviourPVnRT\dfrac{PV}{nRT}nRTPV​> 1.

list.title: Question 3
list.content:
Based on the graph below, choose the correct statement that describes the relationship between pressure and temperature for a fixed mass and volume of a gas?

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/a5b7d708-dada-487b-9f1b-ee2fb3f45b47/images/02187be4-3809-445d-b70e-4ae6dde3de0d/1.3-36.png)

A.\hspace{1em}Pressure is inversely proportional to the absolute temperatureB.\hspace{1em}Pressure is directly proportional to the square of the absolute temperatureC.\hspace{1em}Pressure is inversely proportional to the square of the absolute temperatureD.\hspace{1em}Pressure is directly proportional to the absolute temperature
list.markScheme: DExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:The graph of P vs T shows a linear graph (straight line passing through the origin) that rises upward. This graph shows that P is directly proportional to the absolute temperature. As the absolute temperature increases, the pressure of the gas also increases.

list.title: Question 4
list.content: The ideal gas equation is a formula that combines the relationship between pressure, volume, temperature, and the number of moles.Complete the table below by calculating the missing variables of the ideal gas equation.[4]P\mathbf{P}PV\mathbf{V}Vn\mathbf{n}nT\mathbf{T}T(1)0.015m3\quad 0.015\,\textrm{m}^{3}\quad0.015m30.400mol0.400\,\textrm{mol}0.400mol37∘C37\,{}^\circ \mathrm{C}37∘C152,000Pa\quad 152,000\,\textrm{Pa}\quad152,000Pa(2)2.00mol2.00\,\textrm{mol}2.00mol298K\quad 298\,\textrm{K}\quad298K31,000Pa31,000\,\textrm{Pa}31,000Pa0.25m30.25\,\textrm{m}^{3}0.25m3(3)271K271\,\textrm{K}271K250kPa250\,\textrm{kPa}250kPa0.75dm30.75\,\textrm{dm}^{3}0.75dm30.580mol\quad 0.580\,\textrm{mol}\quad0.580mol(4)A256cm3256\,\textrm{cm}^{3}256cm3flask contains0.800g0.800\,\textrm{g}0.800gof a gaseous compound with an empirical formula of CHCl. The pressure and the temperature of the gas are respectively1.00×105Pa1.00\times 10^{5}\,\textrm{Pa}1.00×105Paand373K373\,\textrm{K}373K. Determine the molecular formula of the compound.[4]
list.markScheme:
For (1): Use the ideal gas equation to calculate the pressure of the gas.PV=nRTP=nRTVP=(0.400mol)(8.31J K−1mol−1)(310K)0.015m3=6.9×104Pa✓\begin{aligned}
PV &= nRT \\[3pt]
P &= \dfrac{nRT}{V} \\
P &= \dfrac{(0.400\,\text{mol})(8.31\,\text{J K}^{-1}\,\text{mol}^{-1})(310\,\text{K})}{0.015\,\text{m}^{3}} = \answer{6.9\times 10^{4}\,\text{Pa}}\,  \checkmark
\end{aligned}PVPP​=nRT=VnRT​=0.015m3(0.400mol)(8.31J K−1mol−1)(310K)​=6.9×104Pa​✓​Further Explanation:‾\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation:}}Further Explanation:​Temperature must be given in Kelvin.T(K)=37+273=310KT(\text{K}) = 37 + 273 = 310\,\text{K}T(K)=37+273=310KFor (2): Use the ideal gas equation to calculate for the volume of the gas:PV=nRTV=nRTPV=(2.00mol)(8.31J K−1mol−1)(298K)152000Pa=0.0326m3✓\begin{aligned}
PV &= nRT \\
V &= \dfrac{nRT}{P} \\
V &= \dfrac{(2.00\,\text{mol})(8.31\,\text{J K}^{-1}\,\text{mol}^{-1})(298\,\text{K})}{152000\,\text{Pa}} = \answer{0.0326\,\textrm{m}^{3}}\, \checkmark
\end{aligned}PVVV​=nRT=PnRT​=152000Pa(2.00mol)(8.31J K−1mol−1)(298K)​=0.0326m3​✓​For (3): Use the ideal gas equation to calculate for the number of moles of the gas.PV=nRTn=PVRTn=(31000Pa)(0.25m3)(8.31J K−1mol−1)(271K)=3.4mol✓\begin{aligned}
PV &= nRT \\
n &= \dfrac{PV}{RT} \\
n &= \dfrac{(31000\,\text{Pa})(0.25\,\text{m}^{3})}{(8.31\,\text{J K}^{-1}\,\text{mol}^{-1})(271\,\text{K})} = \answer{3.4\,\textrm{mol}}\, \checkmark
\end{aligned}PVnn​=nRT=RTPV​=(8.31J K−1mol−1)(271K)(31000Pa)(0.25m3)​=3.4mol​✓​For (4): Use the ideal gas equation to calculate the temperature of the gas. Make sure that pressure is in Pascals and volume is in m3^{3}3.PV=nRTT=PVnRT=(250000Pa)(0.00075m3)(0.580mol)(8.31J K−1mol−1)=39K✓\begin{aligned}
PV &= nRT \\
T &= \dfrac{PV}{nR} \\
T &= \dfrac{(250000\,\text{Pa})(0.00075\,\text{m}^{3})}{(0.580\,\text{mol})(8.31\,\text{J K}^{-1}\,\text{mol}^{-1})} = \answer{39\,\text{K}}\, \checkmark
\end{aligned}PVTT​=nRT=nRPV​=(0.580mol)(8.31J K−1mol−1)(250000Pa)(0.00075m3)​=39K​✓​Further Explanation:‾\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation:}}Further Explanation:​Volume must be given in m3^33.V=(0.75dm3)(1m31000dm3)=0.00075m3V = (0.75\,\text{dm}^3)\left(\dfrac{1\,\text{m}^3}{1000\,\text{dm}^3}\right) = 0.00075\,\text{m}^3V=(0.75dm3)(1000dm31m3​)=0.00075m3Mgas=(0.800g)(8.31J K−1mol−1)(373K)(1.00×105Pa)(256×10−6m3)=96.9gmol−1✓M_{gas} = \dfrac{(0.800\,\text{g})(8.31\,\text{J K}^{-1}\,\text{mol}^{-1})(373\,\text{K})}{(1.00\times 10^{5}\,\text{Pa})(256\times 10^{-6}\,\text{m}^{3})} = \answer{96.9\,\text{g}\,\text{mol}^{-1}}\, \checkmarkMgas​=(1.00×105Pa)(256×10−6m3)(0.800g)(8.31J K−1mol−1)(373K)​=96.9gmol−1​✓MCHCl=12.01+1.01+35.45=48.47gmol−1✓M_{\ce{CHCl}} = 12.01 + 1.01 + 35.45 = \answer{48.47\,\text{g}\,\text{mol}^{-1}}\, \checkmarkMCHCl​=12.01+1.01+35.45=48.47gmol−1​✓96.9g mol−148.47g mol−1\dfrac{96.9\textrm{\ g mol}^{-1}}{48.47\textrm{\ g mol}^{-1}}48.47g mol−196.9g mol−1​≈2✓\checkmark✓The molecular formula isCX2HX2ClX2\ce{C2H2Cl2}CX2​HX2​ClX2​✓\checkmark✓Further Explanation:‾\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation:}}Further Explanation:​Step 1: Use the ideal gas equation to calculate the molar mass of the gas:PV=nRT=(mM)RTPV = nRT = \left(\dfrac{m}{M}\right)RTPV=nRT=(Mm​)RTTherefore,M=mRTPVM = \dfrac{mRT}{PV}M=PVmRT​Step 2: Calculate the empirical formula molar mass.Step 3: Determine the molecular formula.

Calculate the moles of butanol that were combusted.[2]Determine the density of liquid butanol in g cm−3^{-3}−3.[1]

to determine moles of water:nHX2On_{\ce{H2O}}nHX2​O​=PVRT\dfrac{PV}{RT}RTPV​Use the moles of water found and the ratio from the balanced equation to determine the moles of butanol.nbutanol=nHX2O×1molCX4HX9OH5molHX2On_{butanol} = n_\ce{H2O}\times \dfrac{1\,\text{mol }\ce{C4H9OH}}{5\text{mol }\ce{H2O}}nbutanol​=nHX2​O​×5molHX2​O1molCX4​HX9​OH​Recall that 1 J = 1 kPa dm3^33= 1 Pa m3^33Convert temperature to K by adding 273.mbutanol=0.01366molCX4HX9OH×74.14gCX4HX9OH1molCX4HX9OH=1.013gCX4HX9OHm_{butanol} = 0.01366\,\text{mol }\ce{C4H9OH}\times \dfrac{74.14\,\text{g }\ce{C4H9OH}}{1\,\text{mol }\ce{C4H9OH}} = 1.013\,\text{g }\ce{C4H9OH}mbutanol​=0.01366molCX4​HX9​OH×1molCX4​HX9​OH74.14gCX4​HX9​OH​=1.013gCX4​HX9​OHd=1.013g1.250cm3=0.8103g cm−3✓d = \dfrac{1.013\,\text{g}}{1.250\,\text{cm}^3} = \answer{0.8103\,\text{g cm}^{-3}}\,\checkmarkd=1.250cm31.013g​=0.8103g cm−3​✓Further Explanation‾\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}Further Explanation​:m=n×Mm = n \times Mm=n×M;Use the moles of butanol and the molar mass to find the mass of butanol.Then determine the density usingd=mVd = list.title: Question 6
list.content: A sample of gas at the top of a mountain has a pressure of75kPa75\text{ kPa}75kPaand a volume of4.0dm3.4.0\text{ dm}^3.4.0dm3.If that same sample is brought to the bottom of the mountain where the pressure is now100kPa,100\text{ kPa},100kPa,what is the new volume of the gas assuming that the temperature is kept constant?A.0.75dm3\hspace{1em}0.75\text{ dm}^30.75dm3B.0.19dm3\hspace{1em}0.19\text{ dm}^30.19dm3C.3.0dm3\hspace{1em}3.0\text{ dm}^33.0dm3D.5.3dm3\hspace{1em}5.3\text{ dm}^35.3dm3
list.markScheme: CExplanation:‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation:}}Explanation:​This question is answered using the Ideal Gas Law equation,PV=nRT.PV = nRT.PV=nRT.It is assumed that the moles of the gas are the same and the temperature remains constant, so we can setPVPVPVfor each scenario to be equal to each other:P1V1=P2V2P_1V_1 = P_2V_2P1​V1​=P2​V2​whereP1V1P_1V_1P1​V1​is  the pressure and volume at the top of the mountainP2V2P_2V_2P2​V2​isthe pressure and volume at the bottom of the mountainRearranging,V2=P1V1P2=(75kPa)(4.0dm3)100kPa=3.0dm3V_2 = \dfrac{P_1V_1}{P_2} = \dfrac{(75\text{ kPa})(4.0\text{ dm}^3)}{100\text{ kPa}} = \answer{3.0\text{ dm}^{3}}V2​=P2​P1​V1​​=100kPa(75kPa)(4.0dm3)​=3.0dm3​

list.title: Question 7
list.content: Based on the table below, what is the correct calculation to determine the final volume of a fixed mass of gas:InitialFinalPressure (atm)1.001.60Temperature (∘^\circ∘C)2010Volume (dm3^33)5.00?A.\hspace{1em}(1.00atm)(5.00dm3)(283K)(1.60atm)(293K)\dfrac{(1.00 \ \textrm{atm})(5.00 \  \textrm{dm}^3)(283 \ \textrm{K})}{(1.60\ \textrm{atm})(293\ \textrm{K})}(1.60atm)(293K)(1.00atm)(5.00dm3)(283K)​B.\hspace{1em}(1.00atm)(5.00dm3)(10∘C)(1.60atm)(20∘C)\dfrac{(1.00 \textrm{\ atm})(5.00 \ \textrm{dm}^3)(10 \ ^\circ\mathrm{C})}{(1.60 \textrm{\ atm})(20 \  ^\circ\mathrm{C})}(1.60atm)(20∘C)(1.00atm)(5.00dm3)(10∘C)​C.\hspace{1em}(1.60atm)(5.00dm3)(20∘C)(1.00atm)(10∘C)\dfrac{(1.60 \textrm{\ atm})(5.00\ \textrm{dm}^3)(20 ^\circ\mathrm{C})}{(1.00 \textrm{\ atm})(10 ^\circ\mathrm{C})}(1.00atm)(10∘C)(1.60atm)(5.00dm3)(20∘C)​D.\hspace{1em}(1.60atm)(5.00dm3)(283K)(1.00atm)(293K)\dfrac{(1.60 \textrm{\ atm})(5.00\ \textrm{dm}^3)(283\textrm{\ K})}{(1.00 \textrm{\ atm})(293\textrm{\ K})}(1.00atm)(293K)(1.60atm)(5.00dm3)(283K)​
list.markScheme: AExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Ideal gas equation:PV=nRTPV= nRTPV=nRTThe number of moles is the same since there is a fixed mass of gas, and R is a constant.P1V1=nRT1P_1V_1= nRT_1P1​V1​=nRT1​andP2V2=nRT2P_2V_2 = nRT_2P2​V2​=nRT2​The temperature must be measured on the absolute scale, in K.Using the combined gas law equation,P1V1T1=P2V2T2\dfrac{P_1V_1}{T_1} = \dfrac{P_2V_2}{T_2}T1​P1​V1​​=T2​P2​V2​​we can derive the expression:V2=P1V1T2P2T1=(1.00atm)(5.00dm3)(283K)(1.60atm)(293K)V_2 = \dfrac{P_1V_1T_2}{P_2T_1} = \dfrac{(1.00\,\text{atm})(5.00\,\text{dm}^3)(283\,\text{K})}{(1.60\,\text{atm})(293\,\text{K})}V2​=P2​T1​P1​V1​T2​​=(1.60atm)(293K)(1.00atm)(5.00dm3)(283K)​10∘C+273=283K10\,{}^\circ\mathrm{C} + 273 = 283\,\text{K}10∘C+273=283K20∘C+273=293K20\,{}^\circ\mathrm{C} + 273 = 293\,\text{K}20∘C+273=293K

list.title: Question 8
list.content: Under which conditions would a gas deviate the most from the ideal gas model?A.\hspace{1em}1 atm, 298 KB.\hspace{1em}200 atm, 25∘^\circ∘CC.\hspace{1em}200 kPa, 25∘^\circ∘CD.\hspace{1em}100 kPa, 298 K
list.markScheme: BExplanation:‾\underline{\text{Explanation:}}Explanation:​The student must understand that gases deviate from an ideal gas when the temperature is low and when the pressure is high.At low temperatures, the particles move slower and thus are able to form more intermolecular forces.At high pressure the particles are closer together, also allowing for more plentiful attractive forces.In both of these cases, intermolecular forces of attraction cannot be assumed to be negligible and so the gas under those conditions is no longer considered an ideal gas.This question is categorized as medium because the student needs to carefully consider the answer choices. A pressure of 1 atm is the same as 100 kPa. Likewise, 298 K is the same as 25∘^\circ∘C. A pressure of 200 kPa, while higher, is not high enough to drastically increase attractive forces. A pressure of 200 atm would be consistent with the pressure in a compressed gas cylinder when the gas is in liquid form, and is therefore not behaving as an ideal gas.

list.title: Question 9
list.content: Automobile airbags are inflated withNX2\ce{N2}NX2​, a byproduct of sodium azide decomposition, according to the following reaction.2NaNX3(s)→2NaX(s)+3NX2(g)\ce{2 NaN_{3(s)} -> 2 Na_{(s)} + 3 N_{2(g)}}2NaNX3(s)​​​2NaX(s)​​+3NX2(g)​​Calculate the mass (in grams) of sodium azide needed to generate0.070.07 \,0.07m3^{3}3ofNX2\ce{N2}NX2​at1.01×1051.01 \times 10^{5} \,1.01×105Pa and26.0∘26.0 ^\circ26.0∘C.
list.markScheme:
Step 1:  Calculate the number of moles ofNX2\ce{N2}NX2​produced in the reaction.nN2=PVRT=(1.01×105Pa)(0.07m3)(8.31JK−1mol−1)(299K)=2.84mol N2✓n_{N_2} = \dfrac{PV}{RT} =
\dfrac{(1.01 \times 10^{5}\,\textrm{Pa})(0.07\,\textrm{m}^{3})}{(8.31\,\textrm{J}\,\textrm{K}^{-1}\,\textrm{mol}^{-1})(299\,\textrm{K})} = \answer{2.84\,\textrm{mol N}_2}  \checkmarknN2​​=RTPV​=(8.31JK−1mol−1)(299K)(1.01×105Pa)(0.07m3)​=2.84mol N2​​✓Notice Pa m3^33= kPa dm3^33= J.Step 2: Use the mole ratio from the balanced chemical equation to calculate the number of moles of sodium azide reacted.nNaN3=(2.84molNX2)(2molNaNX33molNX2)=1.89molNaNX3✓n_{NaN_3} = \left(2.84\, \textrm{mol}\, \ce{N2}\right)\left(\frac{2\,\textrm{mol}\,\ce{NaN_{3}}}{3\,\textrm{mol}\,\ce{N2}}\right) = \answer{1.89\, \textrm{mol} \, \ce{NaN3}}  \checkmarknNaN3​​=(2.84molNX2​)(3molNX2​2molNaNX3​​)=1.89molNaNX3​​✓Step 3:  Calculate the mass ofNaNX3\ce{NaN3}NaNX3​using the molar mass.mNaN3=nM=1.89mol×65.02gmol−1=123gNaNX3✓m_{NaN_3} = n M = 1.89 \, \textrm{mol} \times 65.02\ \textrm{g} \ \textrm{mol}^{-1} = \answer{123\,\textrm{g} \, \ce{NaN3}} \checkmarkmNaN3​​=nM=1.89mol×65.02gmol−1=123gNaNX3​​✓

list.title: Question 10
list.content: A sample of oxygen gas with volumeV1V_1V1​is at pressure1.00×105Pa1.00\times\ 10^5\,\text{Pa}1.00×105Pa. At constant temperature, what is the pressure ifV1V_1V1​is halved?A.2.00×105Pa\hspace{1em}2.00\times 10^5\,\text{Pa}2.00×105PaB.5.00×104Pa\hspace{1em}5.00\times 10^4\,\text{Pa}5.00×104PaC.5.00×105Pa\hspace{1em}5.00\times 10^5\,\text{Pa}5.00×105PaD.2.00×104Pa\hspace{1em}2.00\times 10^4\,\text{Pa}2.00×104Pa
list.markScheme: AExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:According to Boyle's Law, at constant temperature:P1V1=P2V2P_1V_1 = P_2V_2P1​V1​=P2​V2​Rearranging,P2=P1V1V2=P1V112V1=2P1P_2 = \dfrac{P_1V_1}{V_2} = \dfrac{P_1V_1}{\frac{1}{2}V_1} = 2P_1P2​=V2​P1​V1​​=21​V1​P1​V1​​=2P1​P2=2.00×105PaP_2 = \answer{2.00\times 10^5\,\text{Pa}}P2​=2.00×105Pa​

list.title: Question 11
list.content: 14.01g14.01\,\text{g}14.01gof nitrogen gas (NX2\ce{N2}NX2​) is reacted with excessHX2\ce{H2}HX2​. What volume of ammonia (NHX3\ce{NH3}NHX3​) gas would be produced at STP? The molar volume of a gas at STP is22.7dm322.7\,\text{dm}^322.7dm3.NX2(g)+3HX2(g)→2NHX3(g)\ce{N2(g) + 3H2(g) -> 2NH3(g)}NX2​(g)+3HX2​(g)​2NHX3​(g)A.11.4dm3\hspace{1em} 11.4\,\text{dm}^311.4dm3B.22.7dm3\hspace{1em}\,22.7\,\text{dm}^322.7dm3C.34.1dm3\hspace{1em}\,34.1\,\text{dm}^334.1dm3D.45.4dm3\hspace{1em}\,45.4\,\text{dm}^345.4dm3
list.markScheme: BExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Calculate the number of moles of ammonia gas (NHX3\ce{NH3}NHX3​) that will be produced from14.01g14.01\,\text{g}14.01gof nitrogen gasNX2\ce{N2}NX2​.n(NX2)=mM=14.01g28.02gmol−1=0.5moln(\ce{N2}) = \dfrac{m}{M} = \dfrac{14.01\,\text{g}}{28.02\,\text{g}\,\text{mol}^{-1}} = 0.5\,\text{mol}n(NX2​)=Mm​=28.02gmol−114.01g​=0.5moln(NHX3)=(n(NX2))(2)=(0.5)(2)=1.0moln(\ce{NH3}) = (n(\ce{N2}))(2) = (0.5)(2) = 1.0\,\text{mol}n(NHX3​)=(n(NX2​))(2)=(0.5)(2)=1.0molCalculate the volume of ammonia gas produced at STP.V=n×molarvolume=(1.0mol)(22.7dm3mol−1)=22.7dm3V = n \times \mathrm{molar\, volume} = (1.0\,\text{mol})(22.7\,\text{dm}^3\,\text{mol}^{-1} )= 22.7\,\text{dm}^3V=n×molarvolume=(1.0mol)(22.7dm3mol−1)=22.7dm3

list.title: Question 12
list.content: 6.00 g of ethane gas(Mr≈30)(M_r \approx 30)(Mr​≈30)is placed in a flexible container at STP. The conditions are then changed to a new pressure of 200,000 Pa and a new temperature of 546 K.What is the new volume of the container after equilibrating to the new temperature and pressure?The molar volume of a gas at STP is 22.7 dm3^33.A.22.7dm3\hspace{1em}22.7\,\text{dm}^322.7dm3B.2.27dm3\hspace{1em}2.27\,\text{dm}^32.27dm3C.4.54dm3\hspace{1em}4.54\,\text{dm}^34.54dm3D.9.08dm3\hspace{1em}9.08\,\text{dm}^39.08dm3
list.markScheme: CExplanation:‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation:}}Explanation:​At STP, standard temperature and pressure, the pressure is 100 kPa (100,000 Pa) and the temperature is 0∘^\circ∘C (273 K). A sample of ethane gas is taken from standard conditions and put into new conditions where the pressure is doubled (200000 kPa) and the temperature is doubled (546 K).The amount of ethane is constant through the experiment:nCX2HX6=mM=6.00g30g mol−1=0.200moln_\ce{C2H6} = \dfrac{m}{M} = \dfrac{6.00\,\text{g}}{30\,\text{g mol}^{-1}} = 0.200\,\text{mol}nCX2​HX6​​=Mm​=30g mol−16.00g​=0.200molUsing the molar volume of a gas at STP, we can deduce the original volume of the gas:V1=nVm=0.200mol×22.7dm3mol−1=4.54dm3V_1 = n V_m = 0.200\,\text{mol}\times 22.7\,\text{dm}^3\,\text{mol}^{-1} = 4.54\,\text{dm}^3V1​=nVm​=0.200mol×22.7dm3mol−1=4.54dm3The final volume of the gas can be determined from the combined gas law:P1V1T1=P2V2T2\dfrac{P_1V_1}{T_1} = \dfrac{P_2V_2}{T_2}T1​P1​V1​​=T2​P2​V2​​Solving forV2V_2V2​:V2=P1V1T2T1P2V_2 = \dfrac{P_1V_1T_2}{T_1P_2}V2​=T1​P2​P1​V1​T2​​;Logically, the pressureP2P_2P2​and the temperatureT2T_2T2​doubled, so the volumeV2V_2V2​remains the same. Mathematically,V2=100000Pa×4.54dm3×546K273K×200000PaV_2 = \dfrac{100000\,\text{Pa}\times 4.54\,\text{dm}^3\times 546\,\text{K}}{273\,\text{K}\times 200000\text{Pa}}V2​=273K×200000Pa100000Pa×4.54dm3×546K​The final volume of ethane is 4.54 dm3^33.

list.title: Question 13
list.content: A500cm3500\,\text{cm}^3500cm3flask is weighed empty.  After a chemical reaction was conducted, a gas was collected at SATP conditions.  The flask was found to increase in mass by1.43g.1.43\,\text{g}.1.43g.What is the name of the gas collected?A.\hspace{1em}HydrogenB.\hspace{1em}OxygenC.\hspace{1em}Carbon dioxideD.\hspace{1em}Chlorine
list.markScheme: DExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:At SATP conditions(P=100kPa,T=298.15K)(P = 100 \textrm{\ kPa}, T = 298.15 \textrm{\ K})(P=100kPa,T=298.15K), the ideal gas law can be used to deduce the molar mass of the unknown gas. Starting fromPV=nRT,PV=nRT,PV=nRT,and substitutingn=mM,n = \frac{m}{M},n=Mm​,we obtainPV=mRTMPV = \dfrac{mRT}{M}PV=MmRT​which rearranges toM=mRTPVM = \dfrac{mRT}{PV}M=PVmRT​Converting the volume todm3\textrm{dm}^3dm3(because1J=1kPa dm3),1 \textrm{\ J} = 1 \textrm{\ kPa dm}^3),1J=1kPa dm3),and substituting the given valuesM=1.43g×8.31J mol−1×298.15K100 kPa×0.500dm3=70.9g mol−1M = \dfrac{1.43 \textrm{\ g} \times 8.31 \textrm{\ J mol}^{-1} \times 298.15 \textrm{\ K}}{\textrm{\ 100 \textrm kPa} \times {0.500 \textrm{\ dm}^3}} = 70.9 \textrm{\ g mol}^{-1}M=100kPa×0.500dm31.43g×8.31J mol−1×298.15K​=70.9g mol−1Comparing this value with the molar masses of the candidate gases we can identify the unknown: hydrogen(HX2,2.02g mol−1),(\ce{H2}, \ 2.02 \textrm{\ g mol}^{-1}),(HX2​,2.02g mol−1),oxygen(OX2,32.00g mol−1),(\ce{O2},\ 32.00 \textrm{\ g mol}^{-1}),(OX2​,32.00g mol−1),carbon dioxide(COX2,44.01g mol−1),(\ce{CO2},\ 44.01 \textrm{\ g mol}^{-1}),(COX2​,44.01g mol−1),and chlorine(ClX2,70.90g mol−1).(\ce{Cl2},\ 70.90 \textrm{\ g mol}^{-1}).(ClX2​,70.90g mol−1).The measured value corresponds to chlorine.This is a challenging question because it requires students to combine experimental data with the ideal gas equation to infer an unknown identity, rather than relying on a direct recall of facts.

list.title: Question 14
list.content: Sodium azide is an ionic compound found within the airbags of some older cars. The airbag is deployed as a safety feature in the event of an accident. In this application, the sodium azide decomposes rapidly, and the gas formed inflates the airbag.The decomposition of sodium azide under these conditions is given below.2NaNX3(s)→2Na(s)+3NX2(g)\ce{2NaN3(s)-> 2Na(s) + 3N2(g)}2NaNX3​(s)​2Na(s)+3NX2​(g)Suggest the formula and charge for the azide ion.[1]A typical airbag requires65.0dm365.0\,\text{dm}^{3}65.0dm3of nitrogen gas for complete inflation at STP. Using section222of the data booklet, calculate the mass of sodium azide that the airbag must contain for this purpose.[4]
list.markScheme: The ion azide isNX3X−\ce{N3^-}NX3​X−✓\checkmark✓Award0ifchargeis(3−)\,{Award \ 0 \ if \ charge \ is\ (3-)}Award0ifchargeis(3−)Further Explanation:‾\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation:}}Further Explanation:​Na\ce{Na}Nais in group 1; therefore, the ion formed isNaX1+.\ce{Na^1+}.NaX1+.The charges of the ions must cancel out to give an overall neutral compound.n(NX2)=Vmolarvolume=65.0dm322.7dm3mol−1=2.86mol✓n(\ce{N2}) = \dfrac{V}{\textit{molar volume}}=\dfrac{65.0\,\text{dm}^{3}}{22.7\,\text{dm}^{3}\,\text{mol}^{-1}} = 2.86\,\text{mol}\,\checkmarkn(NX2​)=molar volumeV​=22.7dm3mol−165.0dm3​=2.86mol✓Mole ratio 2:3 applied for number of moles of sodium aziden(NaNX3)=(2.86)(23)=1.91mol✓n(\ce{NaN3}) = (2.86) \left(\dfrac{2}{3}\right)= 1.91\,\text{mol}\,\checkmarkn(NaNX3​)=(2.86)(32​)=1.91mol✓Molar mass for sodium azide calculated =65.02gmol−1✓65.02\,\text{g}\,\text{mol}^{-1}\,\checkmark65.02gmol−1✓m(NaNX3)=n×M=(1.91mol)(65.02gmol−1)=124gm(\ce{NaN3}) = n\times M = (1.91\,\text{mol})(65.02\,\text{g}\,\text{mol}^{-1}) = \answer{124\text{g}}m(NaNX3​)=n×M=(1.91mol)(65.02gmol−1)=124g​(3 sf)✓\checkmark✓Further Explanation:‾\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation:}}Further Explanation:​The number of moles of gas at STP is calculated as volume divided by molar gas volume(22.7dm3mol−1)(22.7\,\text{dm}^3\text{mol}^{-1})(22.7dm3mol−1)M(NaNX3)=22.99+(14.01)(3)=65.02gmol−1M(\ce{NaN3}) = 22.99 + (14.01)(3) = 65.02\,\text{g}\,\text{mol}^{-1}M(NaNX3​)=22.99+(14.01)(3)=65.02gmol−1

list.title: Question 15
list.content: Which of the following gases most closely aligns with the behavior of an ideal gas?A.BrX2\hspace{1em}\ce{Br2}BrX2​, bromineB.HX2\hspace{1em}\ce{H2}HX2​, hydrogenC.ClX2\hspace{1em}\ce{Cl2}ClX2​, chlorineD.OX2\hspace{1em}\ce{O2}OX2​, oxygen
list.markScheme: BExplanation:‾\underline{\text{Explanation:}}Explanation:​The student must understand the concepts behind an ideal gas which assumes negligent volume and insignificant attractive forces between atoms or molecules.As the molar mass of a chemical species increases, the attractive forces between particles also increase. This causes a deviation from the ideal gas model as the relative molecular mass increases.This question is categorized as medium difficulty because the student must apply logic to the definition of an ideal gas.

list.title: Question 16
list.content: Which statement(s) is (are) correct about real gases?I.\hspace{1.em}Gas particles are considered to have negligible volume.II.\hspace{0.7em}At low temperatures, intermolecular forces exist.III.\hspace{0.4em}At high pressure, real gases behave as ideal gases.A.\hspace{1em}I onlyB.\hspace{1em}I and II onlyC.\hspace{1em}II onlyD.\hspace{1em}II and III only
list.markScheme: CExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Ideal gases are described as moving particles with no volume and no intermolecular forces. In contrast, real gases take into account the small volume of particles and the intermolecular forces that can cause a deviation from the ideal behavior.Statement I is incorrect as it applies to ideal gases only.Real gases behave like ideal gases at high temperatures and low pressures. Statement III is incorrect.At low temperatures, condensed phases exist, and intermolecular forces are significant. Statement II is correct.This question is categorized as medium difficulty as students must thoroughly compare and distinguish ideal and real gases.

list.title: Question 17
list.markScheme: BExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:In the first three minutes, the mass of methanol formed ism(CHX3OH)=4.0g min−1×3min=12.0gm(\ce{CH3OH}) = 4.0 \textrm{\ g min}^{-1} \times 3 \textrm{\ min} = 12.0 \textrm{\ g}m(CHX3​OH)=4.0g min−1×3min=12.0gTo determine the amount of hydrogen gas that reacted we will need to use the molar ratio.  First, find the moles of methanol formed:n(CHX3OH)=mMr=12.0g(12.01+4.04+16.00)g mol−1n\ce{(CH3OH)} = \dfrac{m}{M_r} = \dfrac{12.0\,\text{g}}{(12.01 + 4.04 + 16.00) \textrm{\ g mol}^{-1}}n(CHX3​OH)=Mr​m​=(12.01+4.04+16.00)g mol−112.0g​The balanced chemical reaction shows the ratio ofCHX3OH\ce{CH3OH}CHX3​OHtoHX2\ce{H2}HX2​is 1 : 2, son(HX2)=2×n(CHX3OH)n\ce{(H2)} = 2 \times  n\ce{(CH3OH)}n(HX2​)=2×n(CHX3​OH)The molar volume of hydrogen is22.7×103cm3mol−122.7\times 10^3\,\text{cm}^3\,\text{mol}^{-1}22.7×103cm3mol−1.  To find the volume of hydrogen used over the three minutes, use the relationshipV=nVmV = nV_mV=nVm​:V(HX2)=12.0g×2(12.01+4.04+16.00)g mol−1×22.7×103cm3mol−1V\ce{(H2)} = \dfrac{12.0\,\text{g} \times 2 }{(12.01 + 4.04 + 16.00) \textrm{\ g mol}^{-1}} \times 22.7 \times 10^3 \textrm{\ cm}^3 \textrm{\ mol}^{-1}V(HX2​)=(12.01+4.04+16.00)g mol−112.0g×2​×22.7×103cm3mol−1Simplifying reveals the answer incm3\textrm{\ cm}^3cm3:V(HX2)=12.0×2×22.7×103(12.01+4.04+16.00)\answer{V\ce{(H2)} = \dfrac{12.0 \times 2 \times 22.7 \times 10^3} {(12.01 + 4.04 + 16.00) }}V(HX2​)=(12.01+4.04+16.00)12.0×2×22.7×103​​

list.title: Question 18
list.content: A sample of gas at a certain temperature, pressure, and volume (T1T_1T1​,P1P_1P1​, andV1V_1V1​) undergoes a change in temperature and pressure (T2T_2T2​andP2P_2P2​). What is the new volume (V2V_2V2​)?Before:T1,P1,V1T_1, P_1, V_1T1​,P1​,V1​After:P2=2P1ANDT2=12T1P_2 = 2P_1 \quad \textrm{AND} \quad T_2 = \frac{1}{2} T_1P2​=2P1​ANDT2​=21​T1​A.12V1\hspace{1em}\frac{1}{2} V_121​V1​B.18V1\hspace{1em}\frac{1}{8} V_181​V1​C.14V1\hspace{1em}\frac{1}{4} V_141​V1​D.4V1\hspace{1em}4V_14V1​
list.markScheme: CExplanation:‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation:}}Explanation:​Use the combined gas law:P1V1T1=P2V2T2\dfrac{P_1 V_1}{T_1}= \dfrac{P_2 V_2}{T_2}T1​P1​V1​​=T2​P2​V2​​V2=P1V1T2T1P2=P1V112T1T12P1=12V12=V_2 =\dfrac{P_1 V_1 T_2}{T_1 P_2} =\dfrac{P_1 V_1 \ \frac{1}{2}T_1}{T_1\ 2P_1} =\dfrac{\frac{1}{2}V_1}{2} =V2​=T1​P2​P1​V1​T2​​=T1​2P1​P1​V1​21​T1​​=221​V1​​=14V1\frac{1}{4} V_141​V1​Alternate Method:To answer this question, the student must understand and apply the relationships between temperature, pressure, and volume in the ideal gas model:PV=nRTPV = nRTPV=nRTTherefore,V∝TV \propto TV∝TandP∝1VP \propto \dfrac{1}{V}P∝V1​.Since volume and temperature are directly proportional, an increase in one will result in an increase in the other at the same magnitude.In this case,T2=12T1T_2 = \frac{1}{2}  T_1T2​=21​T1​resulting inV2=12V1V_2 = \frac{1}{2} V_1V2​=21​V1​.Pressure is doubled, but since volume and pressure are inversely proportional, this results inV2=12V1V_2 = \frac{1}{2} V_1V2​=21​V1​.Compounding these effects results inV2=14V1V_2 = \frac{1}{4} V_1V2​=41​V1​.This question is categorized as medium because it requires an understanding of the ideal gas law and proportionalities based onPV=nRTPV = nRTPV=nRT.

list.title: Question 19
list.content:
Which graph depicts the behavior of a fixed amount of an ideal gas at constant temperature?A.\hspace{0em}B.\mbox{}\\[-30pts]

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/2e328213-b8b3-4d4b-8e08-001a02815f7c/images/9586b562-a724-4700-8648-f80b6cc09ee9/CH1226a.png)

\mbox{}\\[-30pts]

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/2e328213-b8b3-4d4b-8e08-001a02815f7c/images/85d6b7c7-0a9a-438d-91b4-42e6561c0767/CH1226b.png)

C.D.\mbox{}\\[-30pts]

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/2e328213-b8b3-4d4b-8e08-001a02815f7c/images/2c47e38d-63db-449a-9d59-ae78aa73e245/CH12261c.png)

\mbox{}\\[-30pts]

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/2e328213-b8b3-4d4b-8e08-001a02815f7c/images/ef61e732-30a3-4a19-938e-e398139c55e0/CH1226d.png)
list.markScheme:
CExplanation:‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation:}}Explanation:​At constant temperature, an ideal gas obeys Boyle's law, so the productPV=constant.PV = \textrm{constant}.PV=constant.WhenVVVis plotted againstP,P,P,the curve must therefore be a  hyperbola because volume decreases inversely as pressure increases. If instead1V\frac{1}{V}V1​is plotted againstP,P,P,the two quantities are directly proportional and produce a straight line through the origin. Finally, a plot ofPVPVPVvs.PPPshould be a horizontal line, sincePVPVPVdoes not change with pressure for an ideal gas at fixed temperature.For ideal gases:

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/2e328213-b8b3-4d4b-8e08-001a02815f7c/images/c4710df2-772b-4aba-993e-dc6c21b2d238/CH1226hyperbola.png)



![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/2e328213-b8b3-4d4b-8e08-001a02815f7c/images/0583432a-e106-4649-84a9-1df1388166c9/Screenshot%202025-09-23%20at%202.20.38%E2%80%AFPM.png)



![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/2e328213-b8b3-4d4b-8e08-001a02815f7c/images/93ce3c7f-1dfb-48a0-96ed-91708dd0f328/CH1226PVvsPideal.png)

This question is categorized as hard as students must predict the shape of the curve for the relationship between pressure and volume in an ideal gas at a constant temperature.
